Michelle Barker

ct.css â€“ Letâ€™s Take A Look Inside Your <head> â€” This is a new nifty little diagnostic snippet that helps spot common <head> performance bottlenecksÂ easily.

Harry Roberts

Shortcut sponsor

Leena Sohoni and Addy Osmani

â–¶Â Â What's Coming in WCAG 2.2? â€” This hour-long webinar dives into what you need to know about the upcoming version of the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines, plus how the changes benefit people accessing the web, and when you should adopt the newÂ criteria.

Matthew Putland

These users can turn the â€œreduce motionâ€ setting on â€” hereâ€™s a look at how to respect thatÂ setting.

Theatre.js

Huey: A Multi-Featured, Custom Color Palette Generator â€” One of the nicer of such tools youâ€™ll find. Randomize the palettes or choose a starting color. You can select number of families/tints, then export as PostCSS, SCSS, orÂ Tailwind.

ğŸ‘‹ Hey folks. Chris here, back at the helm after a week away. My thanks to Peter for taking the reins last week. Let's jump into this week's Frontend updates.
__
Chris Brandrick, your editor

Frontend Focus

#â€‹508 â€” September 15, 2021 | Read on the web

Designing Beautiful Shadows in CSS â€” Another excellent tutorial from Josh, this time taking a considered look at how to use CSS to create â€œrich, lush, lifelike shadowsâ€ and do away with the commonly found â€œfuzzy greyÂ boxesâ€.

Josh W Comeau

Reducing the Need for Pseudo-Elements â€” For years, pseudo-elements have helped frontend devs implement creative designs. They still have an important place, but Marcel explains here how we can now leave them behind in some scenarios, thanks to newer CSSÂ properties. This is a lot more interesting than itÂ sounds!

Marcel Moreau

How to Make the Web Accessible â€” Join Jon Kuperman for this video course on website accessibility, covering screen readers, ARIA, focus management, tooling, andÂ more.

Frontend Masters sponsor

Less Absolute Positioning with Modern CSS â€” A solid, practical explainer on how to go about reducing position:absolute usage by leveraging modernÂ CSS.

Ahmad Shadeed

Whatâ€™s New With DevTools: Cross-Browser Edition â€” Learn whatâ€™s new with the developer tools not just in Chrome, but in Firefox, Safari, and Edge too. One of those areas where just a little time spent becoming aware of the possibilities could shave off hours when it comes toÂ debugging(!)

Patrick Brosset

âš¡ï¸ Quick bits:

  • Version 8.4 of Google's automated website auditing tool Lighthouse is available now in Chrome Canary. This post highlights what's new.
  • The W3C's design system is now live.
  • Replay is a new visual debugging tool from some former Firefox Dev Tools team members.
  • The Web Fonts working group has published a Public Working Draft of 'Incremental Font Transfer'. The spec outlines methods to incrementally transfer fonts, allowing clients to load only the portions of the font they actually need, thus speeding up font loads.
  • Mozilla has reverse engineered the way Microsoft sets Edge as default in Windows 10, enabling Firefox to quickly make itself the default.

ğŸ“™ Tutorials, Articles & Opinion

A Deep-Dive into VideoNG â€” If youâ€™ve ever wondered how video rendering works in Chromium this detailed article covers just that, along with its evolution over the last fewÂ years.

Dale Curtis (Google)

overscroll-behavior â€” What you need to know about this CSS property (it controls whether an element will use â€˜scroll chainingâ€™ orÂ not).

Mojtaba Seyedi

Developer Decisions For Building Flexible Components â€” A walk through of the decision process of taking a seemingly simple design for a component (often presented as a static mock-up) and deciding how best to translate it into code â€” keeping in mind the needs of both users and contentÂ authors.

Michelle Barker

Implementing Batch Editing in an Angular Data Grid the Easy Way â€” Use this tutorial to learn how to use Kendo UI for Angular to create a Data Grid that allows updates and saves inÂ bulk.

Progress Kendo UI for Angular sponsor

Orchestrating Complexity with Web Animations API â€” Thereâ€™s lots to learn in the Web Animations API, as such hereâ€™s a how-to looking at learning both timing and playback controls â€” a good foundation/startingÂ point.

Kirill Myshkin

Grainy Gradients â€” This tutorial looks at how generate colorful noise to add texture to a gradient using only a small amount of CSS and SVG. There's code demo's here and what you need to know in regards to browser support. It's a neatÂ effect.

Jimmy Chion

Modernising CSS Infrastructure in DevTools â€” A look at the history of CSS in DevTools, and the future plans for migrating to CSS ModuleÂ Scripts.

Kriti Sapra (Google)

Bundling Non-JavaScript Resources â€” Learn how to import and bundle various types of assets from JavaScript in a way that works both with browsers andÂ bundlers.

Ingvar Stepanyan (Google)

Build Internal Tools in Minutes with Retool, Where Visual Programming Meets the Power of Real Code

Retool sponsor

Kevin Powell

The Story Behind TryShape, A Showcase for the CSS clip-pathÂ Property
Tapas Adhikary

How to Optimize Button Microcopy: Seven Suggestions with Examples
Maria Panagiotidi

Jobs

Walmart is Hiring Software Engineers â€” Code at scale, Fortune 1 scale. Learn more about Software Engineering opportunities atÂ Walmart.
Walmart Global Tech

Frontend Engineer (m/f/x) â€” Grow & work in our cross functional squads in an amazing environment, providing a personal educational budget and 30d ofÂ vacation.
HOMEDAY

Find Frontend Engineering Jobs with Hired â€” Create a profile on Hired to connect with hiring managers at growing startups and Fortune 500 companies. It's free forÂ job-seekers.
Hired

ğŸ”§ Code, Tools and Resources

Tailwind Mobile: Mobile UI Components Built with TailwindÂ CSS â€” Includes lots of utilities and components with a native iOS or Material Design look, currently available for React, with plans for Svelte and Vue in theÂ future.

Vladimir Kharlampidi

Pollen: A Library of CSS Variables Inspired by Tailwind â€” Features include no build process, no framework dependencies, and they can be used in external CSS, inline styles, andÂ CSS-in-JS.

Peppercorn

Starback.js: Create a Beautiful Falling Star Background â€” This is a pretty specific feature to add to a website and wonâ€™t be useful for most projects, but the demo is pretty neat and the API allows you to customize the speed and look of the fallingÂ stars.

Ahmad Saugi
